title: 113_hr5133
content: The Act titled "Protecting Employees and Retirees in Municipal Bankruptcies Act of 2014" determines eligibility for municipalities to be debtors under Chapter 9 of Title 11 of the United States Code. The Act "Protecting Employees and Retirees in Municipal Bankruptcies Act of 2014" amends Section 109(c) of title 11, United States Code by clarifying the term "good faith" for creditors who are employees or retirees, changing "impracticable" to "impossible", and adding a requirement for clear and convincing evidence to satisfy the subsection. The Act "Protecting Employees and Retirees in Municipal Bankruptcies Act of 2014" amends Section 109(c) of title 11, United States Code by clarifying the term "good faith" for creditors who are employees or retirees, changing "impracticable" to "impossible", and adding a requirement for clear and convincing evidence to satisfy the subsection. Additionally, the Act repeals the limitation on authority to issue stay pending appeal and allows for a direct immediate appeal to the Court of Appeals for determinations made by a bankruptcy court regarding debtor eligibility under chapter 9 of title 11. The appeal will be reviewed and heard de novo on an expedited basis, and the doctrine of equitable mootness will not apply to these appeals. The Act "Protecting Employees and Retirees in Municipal Bankruptcies Act of 2014" amends Section 109(c) of title 11, United States Code by clarifying the term "good faith" for creditors who are employees or retirees, changing "impracticable" to "impossible", and adding a requirement for clear and convincing evidence to satisfy the subsection. Section 943 of title 11, United States Code is amended to include provisions for modifying collective bargaining agreements and retiree benefits protected by nonbankruptcy law. The amendment to Section 943 of title 11, United States Code allows for the modification of collective bargaining agreements and retiree benefits. The authorized representative for retirees receiving benefits covered by a collective bargaining agreement is the labor organization signatory to the agreement, unless they no longer represent active employees in the same bargaining unit. If this is the case, the authorized representative will be the labor organization currently representing active employees in that unit, unless the organization elects not to serve or the court rules otherwise. The court may appoint a different representation for individuals receiving retiree benefits if deemed appropriate. If the labor organization declines to represent these individuals or the court decides on different representation, a committee of retired employees may be appointed by the United States trustee upon motion by a party in interest. The court may appoint a different representation for individuals receiving retiree benefits if deemed appropriate. The party requesting relief has the burden of proof. For retired employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement, the court may order the United States trustee to appoint a committee of retired employees if the debtor seeks to modify or not pay retiree benefits. The party making the motion has the burden of proof. The United States trustee shall appoint a committee on a per capita basis to comply with the court's order. The trustee appoints individuals from organizations representing retirees based on membership. A committee cannot recommend changes to retiree benefits unless at least 2/3 of members support the recommendation.
